none.description: Equates to `0`. Use for resetting default spacing styles.

mini.description: Use for small and compact pieces of UI.

xxxSmall.description: Use for small and compact pieces of UI.

xxSmall.description: Use for small and compact pieces of UI.

xSmall.description: Use for small and compact pieces of UI.

small.description: Use for larger and less dense pieces of UI.

medium.description: Use for larger and less dense pieces of UI.

large.description: Use for larger and less dense pieces of UI.

xLarge.description: Use for larger and less dense pieces of UI.

xxLarge.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

xxxLarge.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

huge.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

xHuge.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

xxHuge.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

xxxHuge.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

giant.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

xGiant.description: Use for the largest pieces of UI and for layout elements.

disabled.description:
Disabled buttons have poor contrast and can confuse some users, so avoid them if possible.

Only use disabled buttons if research shows it makes the user interface easier to understand.

A disabled state, also known as an inoperable state, communicates when a component or element isnâ€™t interactive. 

Inoperable states are deemphasized by reducing the enabled state to 32% opacity.

Disabled and inoperable states do not need to meet contrast requirements.
